deck_excerpt: Use Hieratic Seal and Tidying to set up a resilient turn 1 board, then transition to Rokkets and Dragonmaid fusion to take control of the game.
Deck that makes use of the Dark Magician archetype to turbo out 1-turn Quintet Magician or other DM fusion monsters should the need arise.
deck_description: How to 1-turn turbo Quintet Magician Combo#1 Initial cards: 1 Apprentice Illusion Magician 1 Magician Souls. Steps: 1) SS Apprentice by discarding any card to grave 2) Activate Souls and dump DM Girl to GY 3) SS DM Girl using Souls effect 4) XYZ summon Norito using Apprentice and DM Girl 5) XYZ Norito into Ebon Illusion Magician 6) Activate Ebon effect to SS DM 7) Use DM to Link summon Imduk 8) Link summon Predaplant with Ebon + Imduk (You now have 5 different spellcasters in the grave) 9) Activate Predaplant effect to copy Magicalized Fusion and summon Quintet Magician by banishing all 5 spellcasters in GY. Combo#2 Initial Cards: 1 Magicians Rod 1 Magician Souls Steps: 1) Send DM to GY with Souls, then use Souls effect to sp summon DM 2) Normal Rod, search Soul Servant 3) Activate Servant, chose Mahad, then use servant 2nd effect to draw which will sp summon Mahad 4) Overlay Mahad + DM into rank 7 xyz spellcaster (Ebon Illusion or Ebon High). Use Illusion for an extra DM in field If you want. 5) Link summon Anaconda with Ebon + Rod, 6) Use Anaconda to copy Magicalized Fusion to sp summon Quintet Magician. Other Strategies: Your next strategy after Quintet should be to get DM Dragon Knight along with Eternal Soul and Circle with Apprentice acting as your Honest ATK boost. You can get to DM Dragon Knight using Keeper to search Poly, next using Keeper 2nd effect to sp summon DM from grave, and then using poly on DM + Keeper to get DM Dragon Knight. Keeper can also search Fusion Deploy and Magicalized Fusion should you need that. Aside from that, other ways to summon Dragon Knight are: Phantazmay + DM with Secrets or Poly DM + Imduk with Secrets or Poly DM + enemy Dragon using Super Poly DM + Eye of Timaeus Notes: There are other ways to 1-turn turbo Quintet with this deck but they may require 1 more necessary card. The listed combos are the least resource intensive. Should you be wary of hand traps/negates, I suggest you bait them out with your other starting cards first or use Apprentice next since her effect isn't necessary to pull off the combo anyway.

deck_excerpt: The Three Musketeers of Face Cards / Poker Knights, with Makyura to accelerate them.
deck_description:
General strategy:
  • If you open with a Trap Card (usually Joker's Wild or Trap Trick) you can make Isolde, send 4 Equip Spells to summon Makyura the Destructor, then Link away Makyura to trigger its effect. Then you can activate Joker's Wild on your first turn (or Trap Trick which searches Joker's Wild and lets you activate it the same turn). Joker's Wild can send Face Card Fusion or Joker's Straight, depending which one you need at that moment. If it sends Joker's Straight you can retrieve both it and Joker's Wild at End Phase.
  • Isolde can search Kaiki the Unity Star to your hand upon its Link Summon.  If you have Face Card Fusion (or if you can activate Joker's Wild due to Makyura the Destructor's effect and resolve Face Card Fusion that way) while you control Jack/Queen/King's Knight, you can send Arcana Triumph Joker from your Deck to the GY and Kaiki the Unity Star from your hand to the GY to summon Idaten the Conqueror Star, which searches Joker's Knight on summon. Afterward if you use Joker's Straight, you can easily revive Arcana Triumph Joker.
  • Isolde can send Divine Sword - Phoenix Blade as one of its 4 Equip Spells required to summon Makyura the Destructor. This can be retrieved easily and used for discard costs for Joker's Straight, Idaten the Conqueror Star, Arcana Triumph Joker (when destroying Spell Cards), or can be used to power up Arcana Triumph Joker by keeping it in your hand. This card plus the three self-retrieving Joker cards give Arcana Triumph Joker a minimum of 2000 ATK.
  • Kaiki the Unity Star can revive on the opponent's turn if you control a Level 5 or higher Warrior whose current ATK is different from its original ATK. This can be achieved by controlling Arcana Triumph Joker with 1 card minimum in either player's hand (since its effect says it gains ATK, its original ATK is 0), or discarding a card using Idaten the Conqueror Star's effect to allow it to gain ATK, or by equipping Divine Sword - Phoenix Blade or Sword of Deep-Seated to a Level 5 or higher Warrior of your choice. Once Kaiki the Unity Star summons itself, it can initiate a Fusion Summon using itself and Idaten the Conqueror Star as materials to make Shura the Combat Star, or Gilti-Gearfriend the Magical Steel Knight using itself and another Warrior with a different attribute. Shura allows you to make all monsters the opponent controls have 0 ATK during the Battle Phase, while Gilti-Gearfried can negate effects that target it and gains ATK equal to its DEF if you banish a Spell while battling an opponent's monster. It can also attack twice if it was summoned using only materials on the field.
  • The rest of the Extra Deck not mentioned so far is currently in testing and may be subject to change. Feel free to use different cards in those slots. Number 39: Utopia Double is a possible inclusion to secure a quick OTK.
  • A common first turn end board consists of Arcana Extra Joker (summoned using Isolde, Makyura and a third card), Arcana Triumph Joker, and Idaten, with the ability to revive Kaiki to summon Shura on the opponent's turn. You will also likely have Phoenix Blade, Joker's Knight, Joker's Straight and Joker's Wild in your hand at minimum.

deck_name: SUNAVALON DECK,Sunvine Sowing,Burst of Destiny,Specter, Yu-G
deck_description: https://youtu.be/cQWAzcYiY3w

deck_excerpt: A Reaper Format deck that combines an EARTH Warrior Toolbox with mobility and flexibility via trap cards like Spiritual Earth Art - Kurogane to tag mo
deck_description:
A mixture of the search power of Warrior Toolbox with the swarming of Rat Turbo and the maneuverability of Strike Ninja Return, into what is probably a worse version of any. Your Amazoness archetype is the meat of the deck, working as your frontline to bait enemy effects and build a wall of offense while you have The A. Forces active. Their 1100-1500 statline makes them easy to search off of Rat, WLotW, and Last Will, giving you constant field presence with the exception of Paladin, who requires a search off of RotA. Paladin and Tiger are your primary battlers especially while you have one or both The A. Forces active. Chain Master is best to employ early in the duel, as her effect allows you to steal an opponent's monster from their hand, potentially denying them of a valuable resource, at the cost of 1500 Life Points. Finally, Swordswoman is a sneaky option to deal consistent damage to your opponent in battle while protecting your life points. They are supported by several other EARTH and staple monsters depending on the situation you find yourself in. Granmarg is the goon of the deck, removing what is hopefully a critical set card and giving you access to a 2400 body, while Injection Fairy Lily is the deck's back-up win condition, and is searchable by almost any option at your disposal for a surprise attack. Legendary Jujitsu Master serves as your primary wall, forcing opposing attackers to bounce back to the top of the deck to give you some breathing room. Giant Rats and Warrior Lady of the Wasteland serve as your recruiters, and although WLotW may seem like a worse fill-in for a third Giant Rat, her Warrior typing allows her to benefit from the A. Forces where Rat does not, giving you the extra ATK boost you might need. Finally, some staples you see in every deck of the era: Breaker, MoF, Mask and Sangan, who need no explanation.

The predominant trap of this deck is Spiritual Earth Art - Kurogane, which I find to be a criminally underrated tool for EARTH decks. With the exception of Granmarg and your non-EARTH monsters, Kurogane allows you to pull anything in your GY back to your field at a moment's notice, allowing surprise tag-ins with the resources you've accumulated over the course of the duel, and any of your monsters can be relied on depending on the state of the field. Even better, Kurogane can swap a monster that has already attacked in your battle phase for a fresh monster for an additional attack that might just win you the duel. For the same reason, this deck has a method to summon or swap monsters from any location: Last Will and your recruiters can call from the Deck, Dramatic Rescue enables your Amazonesses to switch with a monster in the hand, and Interdimensional Matter Transporter lets you turn any of your monsters into a one-turn Strike Ninja to evade almost anything your opponent has in store for them, and Kurogane and Call of the Haunted obviously access your Graveyard. Other than the staple Spell/Traps, Amazoness Spellcaster allows you trade ATK values with an opponent's monster to potentially go over something troublesome such as the ever-present Cyber Dragon and Monarchs.

In the Side Deck, Millennium Shield exists specifically to counter Skill Drain decks as that trap card is a hazard to this effect-heavy deck. As an EARTH Warrior monster, it is very searchable and triggers the A. Forces, giving it more utility than something like Labyrinth Wall. D.D. Warrior Lady is only here due to not being EARTH, making her less useful in the main deck. Amazoness Blowpiper and Amazoness Archers are available in case your opponent's attacking monsters are just a little too out of reach of your A. Forces boosts. Scapegoat is also important to be mindful of. It's not in the main deck due to the need for open field spaces in case your opponent is vulnerable to an A. Forces Amazoness beatdown, but as the tokens are EARTH, you can trade them with Kurogane for anything in your GY for free, in case you do decide to side the card in.

I find this deck's strength to be in its ability to tempo out an opponent with your constant tag-ins, switches and self-banishes. By retaining and trading field advantage and forcing your opponent's removal effects to be wasted, you can consistently drain your opponent of their options while chipping away at their life points. There are certainly options to consider adding that I chose not to that could boost this deck's efficiency. I believe EARTH monsters like Berserk Gorilla can be useful to drag out of the GY with Kurogane, and obviously this deck chooses to avoid the two biggest Warrior Toolbox monsters of Marauding Captain and D.D. Assailant for the sake of Amazoness Consistency, but so far this build has worked well as it is, even if it remains a work in progress.

The major weaknesses to look out for: Skill Drain as I mentioned, as this is a very monster effect-reliant deck. Jinzo and other anti-trap cards are also something you need to take into account, as losing your surprise switches and stranding your monsters will deprive you of the field presence you need to keep pressure on your opponent. Similarly if your opponent is invested on banishing your cards, it will cut you off from valuable options to tag into when you need them. While I haven't had cause to add it to the side deck, you should consider a copy of Return to be able to recover from an opponent's deck that features a lot of banishment. Finally, always play around Heavy Storm and Dark Hole if you possibly can.

deck_excerpt: A Rikka deck with some Rose techs.
deck_description: "The Rikka are an interesting sort. Women that are born from a plant's flowers during the winter. their original form is a single petal, but as they grow past their infancy, they begin to resemble human girls. They also tend to be fashionable and trendy. for their unusual biology they are referred to as Fairies while their leaders are called Queens. While they often mingle with the outside world, their cultural quirks indicate that they are more comfortable in colder climates, and that they tend to feel drowsy in warmer climes. Scholars speculate that they evolved from sentient fauna that aestivates during the summer. the hypothesis has some evidence as the gardens where the Rikka gather and are born from bloom in the winter. Furthermore they are also more capable of survival in subzero temperatures than humans are, but aren't completely immune to freezing. In fact there were some incidents where some of them froze solid and stayed frozen even as the temperature reached 30 degrees Celsius." A Rikka deck that with some Rose cards as techs. The strategy of the archetype revolves around tributing your mosnters and your opponents mosnters for advantage. As well as access a toolbox of Xyz monsters via the level modification effects of the Rikka Fairies. Snowdrop is the best playmaker of the deck as her ability allows you to make every plant monster have the same level as one of them and she can summon herself and another plant form your hand at the cost of not being able to summon non-Plants that turn. Primula is second as her effect raises the levels of two Plants by two and she can summon herself if a monster if tributed. In between them is Mudan, who can add one of the archtype's backrow to your hand form your deck. Note that these monsters are statistically defense-oriented. I run each at 3. The Fairies come in pairs, with one of them having high DEF and the other having High ATK but more situational effects, as well as an effect to revive themselves under specific circunstances. Of the attack-oriented ones, Cyclamen is the most situational, foe her effect is the opposite of Primulas and it work by tributing her form the hand. Erica has an effect that works like Blackwing - Kalut the Moon Shadow, boosting the stats of a battling Rikka monster by a set amount by tributing her form the hand or field. Hellebore is a handtrap of sorts, stopping opponents effect as long as they target and you have a Rikka onboard. I run 2 of each.   For each pair of fairies there is a queen. The Queens are Xyz monsters that serve as the bosses of the deck. Teardrop being their primary boss, allowing you to tribute any monster and do it during the opponent's turn if she has a Plant as an overlay unit and gains ATK with each tribute. Kanzashi is an analogue of sort so to Number 11: Big Eye. In that they allow you to take an opponents monster. However Kanziashi needs a monster to be tributed first and she affects monsters on the field, also changing them to Plants. Het other effect lets you tribute a plant to take the deathblow an an opponent's effect. Last but not least is Strenna. An adorbale little scater that can recover backrow form the GY and if she is tributed while haivng material lets you bring forht a bigger plant with herself as their overlay unit. This means you can get out monsters like Sacred Tree Beast, Hyperyton, and Teardrop without running the right levels. Of course they'll only have one material in that case, but Hyperyton can get more every turn. The last monster of note is Rikka Petal. She can special summon herself from the GY and also lets you search or mill a Fairy to use their effects. Of course she also plant-locks you, so I can understand if people don't play her as much. I also run 3 Rikka Glamour and one each of Flurries, Sheet and Tranquility. The rose cards I added for the main deck are Ruddy Rose Witch, Witch of the Black Rose, Rose Fairy and Rose Girl. This is a small-ish engine that lets you pull off a Black Rose Dragon or other plays involving Crossrose Dragon or Garden Rose Flora. Other monsters include Parallel eXceed, Evil Thorn, Staysailor Romarin, Tytannial, Princess of Camellias, and of course Plant Staple Lonefire Blossom. For the Extra Deck, besides those already mentioned, I run Number 38: Titanic Galaxy, Number 60: Dugares, Number 87: Queen of the Night, Sunavalon Dryas, Aromaseraphy Jasmine and Marincess Coral Anemone. The side deck includes additional copies of Flurries, Sheet and Tranquility and 3 copies of Rose Lover. As placeholders I also have 3 Effect Veiler and Twin Twisters each. That about sums up my deck for now. I'll make some updates if I can get some Garden Rose Maidens and a Ruddy Rose Dragon. I'll eventually do some test hands to see if there are other changes to make, but for now I'm open to suggestions.
irl deck

deck_excerpt: Amazoness-combo's with cyberse-Link-monsters as support, it can rush fast amazoness-cards together with 'wall'-monsters and other 'boss-monsters' with
deck_description:
Monsters:

Metaltron XII, the True Dracombatant: it gets immunities by the tributes used for the summon if you need an 'immunity'-monster. As the second effect it summons a fusion-monster or synchro-monster from the extra-deck when it gets destroyed.

-possible summons from the extradeck: Crystal Clear Wing Synchro Dragon (for spells/traps), Crystal Wing Synchro Dragon (for monster-effects), Egyptian God Slime (alternative, wall), Amazoness Empress (alternative, amazoness), Amazoness Pet Liger (alternative, amazoness) -possible tributes to summon it: Egyptian God Slime (3 tributes as one card), all other monsters and tokens, Supply Squad, Metal Reflect Slime (alternative to Egyptian God Slime), Call Of The Haunted (you can use the targeted monster too), Amazoness Onslaught (alternative) Amazoness Queen: It gives all Amazoness-monsters battle-damage-immunity, and it is easy to special summon it to rush with amazoness-cards and to force the opponent to play negate-cards. -possible special summons: 1. Fusion Deployment (you can not link- or synchro-summon in the same turn) 2. Amazoness Village (if Amazoness Pet Liger, Amazoness Empress or Amazoness Queen gets destroyed) 3. Amazoness Onslaught (special summoned from the hand in the battle phase) 4. Amazoness Empress (It gets summoned from the Hand, GY or Deck if it gets destroyed.) 5. Amazoness Princess (It can be summoned when Amazoness Princess declares an attack, you can attack monsters with higher atk this way because you can't get destroyed when you attack after the effect, but you will get battle-damage from it, and the effect must work, you also have to discard one card from the hand or the field. Good targets to discard are tokens, Amazoness Queen (because you get one anyway), or Swords of revealing Light (maybe after 1 or 2 rounds if possible) -Amazoness Princess - A good card to play form the start hand because you can get Amazoness Village or Amazoness Onslaught with it, if you have another Amazoness-monster-card, you could also get Amazoness Spy to special summon it. Amazoness Spy - Can be special summoned to get more monsters on the field, can also be fusion summoned with The Earth - Hex-sealed Fusion to get a fast Amazoness Empress or Amazoness Pet Liger Amazoness Sage - Strong with Amazoness Queen or Amazoness Empress to shoot Spells/Traps while having battle-damage-immunity, can be special summoned by Amazoness Princess's effect, the Amazoness-support cards, and searched by Amazoness Call. Cyberse Gadget – A good midgame-card when you have Cosmic Compass or Scapeghost in the graveyard to special summon them as synchro- or link-material. You can also set it in the earlygame to get a token when it gets destroyed, or link summon with it to get the token directly. Clock Wyvern: a good early-game card that is cyberse like Cyberse Gadget to get Splash Mage and Fire Phoenix @Ignister. The 'opener-combo' it to play it as the first normal summon, get the token and summon splash mage, then get Clock Wyvern back with it and summon Fire Phoenix @Ignister with only one monster used. You can later fusion summon it fast with only 2 other effect-monsters, that you can link-summon to Proxy F Magician, to Cyberse Clock Dragon which has then 4500atk (with link-2 material) for one turn of each player, and a 'wall'-effect that works best with Fire Phoenix @Ignister or Linkuriboh. You can also special summon it with Fusion Deployment from the deck, but you must fusion summon it then directly without link-summons, you still trigger the token-effect, so you could use it as 2 free-tributes for Metaltron XII, The True Dracombantant. You also trigger the token-effect by special summoning it from the Graveyard with Call Of The Haunted or Monster Reborn. The Earth - Hex-sealed Fusion: You can use it to get Amazoness Empress or Amazoness Pet Liger with one generic Amazoness-monster. You can not use the tribute-effect to summon Cyberse Clock Dragon because it its not an earth-monster, but this would be not a good play anyway because you wouldn't get the 'fusion-summoned'-effects. You can still use it as substitude for Clock Wyvern with Necro Fusion or Proxy F Magician. Cosmic Compass: A fast token-summoning monster that can be special summoned with Cyberse Gadget from the graveyard and that works in the same turn it gets summoned, so it's good for the earlygame and to rush for link-monsters. Scapeghost: a level-1-tuner and a good token monster that also can be special summmoned with Cyberse Gadget from the graveyard. It's good for Tokens and for synchro-summoning, you get Cyberse Quantum Dragon with 1 Amazoness Queen (level 6), then you could revive it to summon Crystal Wing Synchro Dragon with Cyberse Quantum Dragon (level 7-synchro). With amazoness cards you always have an Amazoness Queen on the field so it's a good support for amazoness-monsters, you could also use two level-3 monsters if you want.   Spells: Amazoness Call, Flawless Perfection of the Tenyi, Supply Squad, Link Burst: draw cards, with amazoness call you always get Amazoness Princess to then get Amazoness Village or Amazoness Onslaught by summoning it, and also get Amazoness Queen with the attack-effect, but you can also get all other amazoness cards, but you can not use it twice in a turn. Flawless Perfection of the Tenyi is the best draw card with tokens that you need for the link-monster-support anyway, you can not use the effect with normal-monsters but you get tokens from Scapegoat, Scapeghost, Cosmic Compass, Clock Wyvern and Cyberse Gadget and you can also set monsters like Scapeghost (flip effect) and amazoness monsters ('battle-damage'-immunity or Amazoness Spy's GY-summon-effect). Link Burst is best with Linkuriboh (graveyard-summon-effect) or Fire Phoenix @Ignister (you can shoot two monsters instead of one , and it also comes back from the graveyard). Amazoness Village, Fusion Deployment, Instant Fusion, Swords of Revealing Light, One-Time Passcode,  Scapegoat, Monster Reborn: Good defensive cards for tokens and special summons, with Amazoness cards it's good to rush for fast wall-effects, with Swords of revealing light the opponent has to decide between it, Amazoness Village and Amazoness Onslaught with negate-cards, so it's also good because it gets 'aggro' and the opponent hast to negate it, you can also discard it with Amazoness Princess's attack-effect. One-time Passcode can be used for fast Cyberse-link-monsters whenever you have it or as a tribute for Amazoness Queen or Metaltron XII, the True Dracombatant.   Traps: Metal Reflect Slime – With it you get a 'wall' as fast as possible by special summoning Egyptian God Slime with it, this protects the other amazoness-combo's. You can also use it to summon Metaltron XII, the True Dracombatant with only one tribute and then get a good 'boss-monster' that negates the opponent cards. Call of the Haunted – good special summon, If you special summon Amazoness Princess with it you can search for another Amazoness card from the deck, and if you summon Amazoness Queen, your Amazoness-monster-cards get undestroyable, if you summon Clock Wyvern you get a token. Necro Fusion - fusion-trap that works good with amazoness cards, amazoness princess's name is in the graveyard also 'amazoness queen, and you cana also use The Earth - Hex-sealed Fusion as material from the graveyard, you can also fusion summon Cyberse Clock Dragon fast with it. Amazoness Onslaught: Amazoness-support card, special summons one amazoness-monster per battle phase fro the hand with +500atk in that battle phase and opponent monsters get banished everytime they fight amazoness-monsters, so the opponent has to clear it especially if you have 'battle-damage'-immunity, it works more than one time, so with Amazoness Call you could even attack all opponent monsters with Amazoness Queen and banish them. If it gets destroyed you get one amazoness-monster special summoned from the graveyard. Lost Wind – good negate that works twice   Extra-deck: Fusion: Thousand-Eyes Restrict – the 'Instant Fusion'-target, 'eats' one monster and can then be used for Linkuriboh Cyberse Clock Dragon – you get 4500atk when you used Link 2 - Proxy F Magician to summon it, for one turn of each player, if you have another link-monster on the field you get a wall-effect that gives target- and attack-immunities to other monsters. You get a spell from the deck if it gets sent to the graveyard by an opponent's card effect (not by battle). Amazoness Empress, Amazoness Pet Liger - High Atk Monsters with good effects that can attack all other monsters with Amazoness Call in the GY. Amazoness Empress is only good with Amazoness Queen, so that both have 'battle-damage'-immunity, then it gets even stronger with more wall-cards. The 'wall'-monsters that you can play are Amazoness Pet Liger, Egyptian God Slime, Cyberse Clock Dragon and Cyberse Quantum Dragon, the other monsters can be used to have more negates and 'boss-monsters'. Egyptian God Slime: Good 'wall'-monster with Amazoness Cards that can be special summoned with one Metal Reflect Slime. The opponent has to attack and to target it first,and it won't get destroyed by battle, so it can defeat any monster in battle that has 3000 or less atk.   Link: Linkuriboh: You can use the tokens from Clock Wyvern, Scapeghost, Scapegoat and Cosmic Compass or Scapeghost, Cosmic Compass and Thousand-Eyes Restrict as level-1-monsters. Splash Mage: It's only used to get more monsters for link summons on the field. You can get Fire Phoenix @Ignister with only one Clock Wyvern, but you can also use it to get a fast Accesscode Talker, and summon as much Link-monsters as possible before it to destroy more cards with it. Saryuja Skull Dread is the only Link-monster that is not Cyberse, so you can not summon it in the same turn after you used the effect, you can also not special summon other monsters after you used it, if they are not cyberse, so you have to special summon amzoness-monsters or token-monsters before you use it if you want to special summon more monsters. With the effect you can special summon Clock Wyvern and Cyberse Gadget in defense position and with effects negated, but you can't summon link monsters because they can't be in defense position, so you have to calculate that if you summon link-4 monsters. Proxy F Magician – Good alternative to Necro Fusion and The Earth - Hex-sealed Fusion, when you have enough tokens, but it only needs generic effect monsters. It can also use itself as fusion material if you summon Cyberse Clock Dragon. Fire Phoenix @Ignister: You can summon it with Clock Wyvern that you can turn to Splash Mage in one turn. It can shoot 2 monsters instead of one if you use Link Burst on it, it is a good 'Wall'-Link-Monster to support Cyberse Clock Dragon and Cyberse Quantum Dragon, because both need a link monster for their 'wall'-effects. Accesscode Talker: The best Link-monster that can also be summoned very fast in the earlygame if you have a token card. You can then special summon Proxy F Magician and Splash Mage if possible to have more Link-monsters in the graveyard and then summon it to destroy a card for every link-monster in the graveyard or on the field. You have to banish them but you can destroy 3-4 cards in one turn, and then have a monster with at least 4300 atk. This can counter most boss-monsters of other deck-combo's if they don't have any negates to stop the summon or destroy-effect. It can also banish itself to destroy another card if you don't need the atk-damage. If you can summon Fire Phoenix @Ignister before you get it, you only need another level-1-Token or 1 Monster, and you already have 5300 atk then. This is nearly as strong as Red-eyes Dark Dragoon was before it got banned, but it does not have the negate power against the otk- and early-lockdown-strategies that are most important to counter somehow if it's possible, it also cannot be summoned with only one spell and it's harder to summon it in the first turn. Saryuja Skull Dread – You have to summon with 4 materials to be effective, then you can draw 4 cards and put 3 back into the deck, to then easily play the right amazoness-combo's with also one more card in the hand. It depends if you have enough tokens and other monsters to play, if it's an effective play, then you can also use the special summon effect to summon one monster from the hand, so it can be fast worth it to summon it. It's also Link-4, so if you have it in the graveyard when you have Accesscode Talker you get 6300atk with it.   Synchro: Cyberse Quantum Dragon: You can summon it with Scapeghost and Amazoness Queen (level 6) or for example with two level-3 monsters instead. It can knock-out all extra-monsters by sending them back to the extra-deck without targeting them. It has to be attacked and targeted when you have another link-monster. It is also possible to summon Crystal Wing Synchro Dragon with another Scapeghost. Crystal Wing Synchro Dragon – One of the targets that are good to summon with Metaltron XII, the True Dracombatant. It would be normally harder to summon it in one turn, and it has a good monster-effect negate, and it's also hard to defeat it in a battle. Crystal Clear Wing Synchro Dragon – One of the targets that are good to summon with Metaltron XII, the True Dracombatant. It would be normally harder to summon it in one turn, and it has a good Spell/trap-negate, you get Clock Wyvern as a wind-monster from the deck to the hand if it gets sent to the graveyard by an opponents card.

deck_excerpt: I wrote about the January and April 2021 OCG Limit Regulations; it is time again for the third one this year.
deck_description: I wrote about the January and April 2021 OCG Limit Regulations; it is time again for the third one this year. Like the last two entries, I enjoyed reading the feedback about them. especially the huge majority of people talking about the quantity of Maxx “C” that they were uncomfortable with, and occasional snark remarks about the region as well. Unfortunately, KONAMI has not yet decided Maxx “C” is problematic in the OCG. So my dear TCG readers, I apologize for the distress this may cause you for the next three months. This article, as per namesake, is about me breaking down the Limit Regulations for the next three months. I will do my best to explain various reasonings behind certain factors with the current metagame in mind. Links: https://www.businessmodulehub.com/blog/everything-you-need-to-know-before-seeing-black-widow-and-luca/ https://pshav.com/everything-to-know-balckwidow-luca/ https://ello.co/emopp23/post/jbdeh0efsjkxa_ykhsi-va http://perencanaan.setjen.pertanian.go.id/index.php/forum/baca/everything-you-need-to-know-before-seeing-black-widow-lucaand-fast-and-furious-9 https://trojanrecords.com/community/profile/akagami/ As a final disclaimer, this is about the OCG July 2021 Ban List. Several cards like Maxx “C” and Sky Striker Mobilize – Engage are not banned, and some cards that “have not been imported” like Decode Talker Heatsoul exist in this metagame.

deck_excerpt: Holy shit this deck is kinda broken.
deck_description:
Hey, it's been a bit. Here's a deck that is really good. I really wish that we would get the new support in a structure deck like the OCG, but it looks like it will be in brothers of legend.

Sooooo, this deck is kinda amazing. Drawing 20 cards in a turn is nuts.  The board is leo with all three ZW + Number 38 + some other stuff that isn't really important.

The deck can OTK really well, and can also stack a bunch of materials onto zeus.

Did I mention you can draw like 20 cards off of change tactics.

Also change tactics is really searchable.

This Deck is about control and tribute opponents Monsters for Obelisk
either using Crossing Souls or Crackdown.
I use Danger! engine to Draw and get Obelisk instead of playin other search cards
because the side effects of the Danger Monsters
even if they get discarded are pretty good for removal
and to get a good board for various Link/Xyz Monsters (i'm still workin' on the Extra Deck)
For Normal Summon you should use Condemned Witch, Reactor Slime or Tellus.
If you need more material on Field you could use Tellus for Link Summon and get a Token for further Plays.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=e5GE-dQ6uj0

Hi Duelists Today I'm showcasing this pretty cool zoodiac handloop deck Yeap a zoodiac handloop combo :0 that banish your opponent hand recurrently "XYZ SHIFT" is a cool tech card, helpful to summon megaclops. Any zoodiac + xyz shift = Megaclops Hope you like this video, take care

deck_name: Court of the Gods - Winged Dragon of Ra OTK - FT King's Court Joker
deck_excerpt: King's Court gives us the key to kill our opponent in one turn with an Egyptian God like  an anime protagonist.
deck_description:
This deck will never be a META-DECK, but it's a complete beast against all other rogue strategies.

You can absolutely summon the three knights up to 3 times in one single turn with your best hand, and even if you don't, Joker's Straight not only makes you summon the three knights, but also gives you an extra normal summon, which you can use to get another set of knights on the field, or even normal summon an egyptian god. Joker's Straight, Joker's Wild and Joker's Knight are definitely the best of this deck, always recycling at the end of either player's turn. Which allows you to play them every single turn.

With Thunderspeed Summon you can normal summon Slifer (even from the deck) or Ra, at the beginning of your turn, during the battle phase (which would allow for a Ra one turn kill) or even during your opponent's turn. (Ra Sphere Mode is also eligible).

Even if you are not capable of ending things with a God, with so many summons of level 4s and 5s, you have access to a lot xzys and link monsters, from Isolde, to Utopia Lightning, Constellar Pleiades and even Zeus in the right stituation.

Court of Card might be a bad second turn card, but it's absolutely useful if you choose to play slifer, or if you brick, which as in any deck, might happen.

Arcana Knight Joker is just a targer for Pot of Prosperity.

Give it a try and make it your own with any changes you may see fit. It has enough hand traps and support to compete in a tournament.

deck_excerpt: My Red-Eyes Deck for Yu-Gi-Oh Legacy of the Duelist -Link Evolution- with possible support for Red-Eyes Dark Dragoon
deck_description: My Red-Eyes Deck for Yu-Gi-Oh Legacy of the Duelist -Link Evolution- with possible support for Red-Eyes Dark Dragoon If you want to put Red-Eyes Dark Dragoon in, i recommend to take Red-Eyes Wyvern out and put Dark Magician in. Summoning: Main way of summoning Monsters is to either have Catalyst Field up and summon your Gemini Monsters without a tribute and activating the Ability on the same Turn. Or use Return of the Red-Eyes and get your Monsters from the Graveyard. Return of Dragon Lords, Red-Eyes Baby Dragon and Red-Eyes Alterantive Dragon also help getting your Red-Eyes on the Field. The later one can get you a Red-Eyes Black Dragon with 4800 ATK. Red-Eyes Fusion is the the Red-Eyes version of Fusion, most of the Time you want Red-Eyes Slash Dragon or Red-Eyes Dark Dragoon. Red-Eyes Flare Metal Dragon and Darkness Metal, the Dragon of Dark Steel can also help getting your Dragons out. Protection: Red-Eyes Slash Dragon and Meteor Dragon Red-Eyes Impact are the Main ways protect your Red-Eyes. Catalyst Field is the main way of getting rid of Spell/Trap Cards and powerfull  Monsters (that are not protected from destruction). Red-Eyes Fang with Chain can get rid of (most) Boss-Monsters, since it doesn't destroy them. As long as you can target the Monster and the effect is not canceled you can turn the Monster into equiptment. Return of the Dragon Lords can also prevent the destruction of one of your Dragons. (Red-Eyes Dark Dragoon can also stop one effect per Turn and destroy up to 2 Monster if put in) Getting Cards: Red-Eyes Insight, Black Metal Dragon and Red-Eyes Baby Dragon are the main ways of getting Cards you need. Since you need to send Red-Eyes to the Graveyard for Red-Eyes Insight it supports summoning or helps getting the second Gearfried the Red-Eyes Iron Knight into the Graveyard for Red-Eyes Slash Dragon. If your Galaxy Satellite Dragon can survive till your Opponents End-Phase you can also get a card on the next turn. But Galaxy Satellite Dragon is mainly in this Deck to help summon Darkness Metal.

deck_name: Utopia With Future support! Meta Potential
deck_excerpt: Utopia with future support, zubabababancho + dodododwarf + onomat engine, Meta Potential
deck_description: The deck is pretty fun to just pick up, You can combo with utopic onomatopoeia and dodododwarf and zubabababancho or you just need ZS ascended sage and another lv 4 monster. with ascended sage you overlay into regular 39: utopia, ZS sage will trigger which will get you the hyper rank up spell, you then overlay into utopia prime, you use rank up spell to xyz into utopia dragner, when dragner is out you detach 2 matierals to ss leo utopia, when leo utopia comes out the hyper spell will activate in grave attaching itself to the leo utopia. you then activate leo to equip twin saber pegasus for a monster negate or tornado bringer so it doesnt get outted by field wipe cards (lightning storm, Raigeki, Dark hole, etc), on the opponents turn you chain graner again to ss either Hope Harbinger as a spell negate or Stealth kragen for a pop on the field, And thats the first combo! The onomat + bancho + Dwarf combo follows the same line but first you need to get ascended sage out on the field. You'll normal summon onomat, activate its effect to ss both dwarf and bancho from hand, xyz into utopic sage, then detaching from utopic sage to ss the ascended sage from deck, from there you overlay the sage and whichever of the Lv 4 you have left following the same line of play as the other combo, this combo does have better perks such as the utopic sage being able to protect one of you utopia monster, and also being able to extend further with the effect of dwarf in grave to ss and bancho on field to ss from grave. there are indeed many more ways to do combos in this deck and to be honest it feels like you'r able to freestyle into whichever combo you want. I hope you try out this deck and it shows a side of something interesting to you.

deck_excerpt:
PK Fire but with Winged Beast and mostly Winds.



Flundereezenuts
deck_description:
This deck in my opinion is extremely fun and really reminds me of the play-style of PK Fire. But first things first, this deck "kinda" solves the problem with flundereeze instantly having to pass after being ashed or imperm, as the simorgh field spell gives you a second normal in some situation and the baby simorgh birbs can sometimes bait a negate, but as it stands, it's still an extremely hard deck to pick up and learn, as your combos really depend on you going first and not drawing a hand full of monsters that require a 1 to 2 tributes to summon, but if you are willing to learn this deck, you will find that a lot of the recent meta decks can't play through Empen, Surprised Raiza and for some really odd reasons, Dark Simorgh.

<hr />

DUMB SYNERGY FILLER :

First, THE SIMORGH FIELD SPELL IS OP AF, HOLY HELL DOES IT HELPS FLUNDEREEZE.

Second, The simorgh birbs triggers the flundereeze's banish effect. (simple enough)

Third, Darkness Simorgh gives flundereeze the option for a negate, but remember you can't special summon the turn you used any of the flundereeze effect. So the main strat with it is to special summon it during your opponent's turn with the effect of the Flundereeze field spell tribute summoning something like Raiza or Empen or you can normal summon it on your turn. Whatever situations suits you.

<hr />

That's all I got to say, but is this deck is hella fun. Really reminds me of PK Fire and really does live up to it's legacy.

deck_excerpt: The decklist referenced in WideWalrus' Noble Knight introduction article, and also the deck they took all the way to finals in the June 2021 YTC!
deck_description: This decklist is the decklist WideWalrus used in the June 2021 YTC tournament, and is also referenced in their Noble Knights article! You can read the article on the Trinity website at this link: https://trinityygo.wixsite.com/trinityygo/onwards-to-camelot

Snake Lair is an aggro-control deck focused on creating disruptive boards turn 1 and following with an otk on turn 2. Overlord, King, and number 38 are the primary disruptive boss monsters and are helped by various hand traps and super polymerization. Lair of darkness is used to build your board using the opponents resources against them. A small reptilianne engine aids the otk.

deck_excerpt: Just thought of this while in uni.
deck_description:
This deck is very situational....

The main strategy is to get lair of darkness onto the field and oppress your opponent's side of the field through tributing there monsters. knightmares help with backrow and special summoned monsters negations(gryphon and phoenix).

diabolos are there for both; lair of darkness synergy and dark world dealings to essentially get a free draw.

Blazing mirror force for millennium seeker special summon and burn damage.

Card advance+ draw of fate for setup.

Everything else is up to you(side deck is also your choice)

deck_excerpt: A Post-DAMA, somewhat memey and Hand-less take on HAT.
deck_description:
"Deep within the jungle, lies a trove of ancient relics. Weapons with the power that erase memories. Ruins of advanced civilizations. However, a tribe of women capable of creating pitfalls and taming dangerous flora and fauna alike serve as the guardians of these ruins, and the ruins themselves still have active security systems. Adventurers seeking these treasures often meet there doom. Pray take proper precautions when trying to rob the ruins these girls guard, lest you become prey to their pets." While I listed this as a Fun/Casual Deck that is mainly because I desire to run of each of the colorful weapons and I know that most of them are too ...subpar to contend with the meta as much (the exceptions being Scythe, Lancea and maybe Chakram, Dagda, Durandal and Moralltach). Regardless I do have a idea on where to take this deck and a desire to seek out feedback on what else can be done to improve this deck apart form removing most of the artifacts. Ahem the general gist is to use the Holes and Artifacts in tandem to but advantage and bait the opponent into destroying my backrow, which will in turn set up for Rank 5 plays the next turn. To that end I'm running Vimana (once Dawn of Majesty releases that is) and Machu Mech as a First and Second turn play as well as Tornado Dragon to pop my own backrow if needed (granted they're there as placeholders until better options come to mind and are better utilized with Vajra or Beagalltach). the rest of the monsters are Traptrixes as well as Dagda and Durendal. I'm planning on a ratio of 3 Sera, 3 Allomerus 1 Cularia and 1 Rafflesia. I seek feedback for this concept with the following questions
  • What Trap Holes should be ran besides Gravedigger's. I'm waiting until the inevitable mega-tin reprint to get those. But I also want to know what other holes are ran alongside that card
  • Are there any cards that recover Banished Traps? They might be useful for later.
  • What other ED monster could be ran in this build besides the obvious (Knightmares, Link-4s, Utopia)? this is mainly to replace the Tornado Dragons.
  • I'm also considering running Utopic Dragner and Chateau Hyuck, but I'm weighing if that would take up too much space (since the later needs material to be of any use)

deck_excerpt: Fallen Utopia? Call Redoer and company! They'll do stuff! (In depth profile)
deck_description:
Stolen Utopia: Breakdown

Howdy! Welcome and thank you for checking out my deck profile! If you bother to read this essay on a children's card game, you will obtain a better understanding of why I made specific card choices, other options for the deck, and some of the optimal end boards.

The Ideal Utopia(?):

As the majority of the play base is aware of, "Utopia" and it's related cards/archetypes have been receiving copious amounts of support within the last two years, whether it be from Lightning Overdrive, Legendary Duelists: Magical Hero, the new Overlay Network: Structure Deck, or King's Court. No matter where you are getting your support from, as long as it's current, it's bound to be playable.
Legendary Duelist: Magical Hero:
First off, I'm not main decking any of the support from this set, but I still figured it'd be worth mentioning how it did give the deck some much needed field presence and searching for said field presence. As I have found, "Time Thief" has better interactions with the Lightning Overdrive support versus Magical Hero's "Zubababancho Gagagacoat" and "Dododowarf Gogogoglove", but I'll elaborate later.
Lightning Overdrive:
This set introduced two new Level 4 "ZS -" monsters and "ZW -" monsters, along with a "Utopia" themed R.U.M. and other "Zexal" Spell/Trap support. "ZS - Ascended Sage" has the inherent Summoning ability that's active while you control no cards. A free body? Yes, exactly, but it gets better with "ZS - Armed Sage." It too has the ability to inherently Special Summon itself, but only if the only monster you control is a Level 4 monster that's not a copy of itself. These two are great cards, they allow you to get to Rank 4 easily and when used as material for the Xyz Summon of a "Utopia" monster, they search for a R.U.M. (Ascended Sage) and a ZW - monster (Armed Sage). As an honorable mention, "Ultimate Dragonic Utopia Ray" the new retrain of "Number C39: Utopia Ray," is the only TCG legal "Utopia Ray" that sees play, but as soon as "Leo Utopia Ray" is available, it'll be the less preferred card. "ZW - Pegasus Twin Saber" is a Level 5 monster with the ability to Special Summon itself if your LP is 2000 or lower than your opponents. Rarely is it going to be used for Xyz Material, more often you'll be equipping it to a "Utopia" monster by a card effect. It has a similar effect to "ZW - Eagle Claw," but it negates monster effects on the field instead of Traps. "ZW - Dragonic Halberd" is the second "ZW -" introduced. Not much else to say other than it can search "Zexal" Spell/Trap cards. The three playable "Zexal" backrow released are "Rank-Up-Magic Zexal Force," "Zexal Construction," and "Zexal Entrust." "Construction" allows you to search "ZW -," "ZS -," other "Zexal" Spell/Traps, or "R.U.M."/"R.D.M.," which is why there is only one "Entrust." Speaking of it, "Entrust" allows you to revive or recover a "Utopia," "ZW -," or "ZS -" monster and during the next turn, if your LP is 2000 or lower than your opponents, you can add one "Zexal" Spell/Trap in your GY to your hand. Finally, "R.U.M. Zexal Force." It works like most "R.U.M." Spells, but it requires the player to summon a "Utopia" or "ZW -" monster, then you place one "ZW -" or "ZS -" monster from your Deck on the top of the Deck. (Not optional if the Xyz Summon goes through.) Lastly, it's GY effect. It too revolves around 2000 LP difference, and it lets you draw a card by banishing it.
Structure Deck: Overlay Universe
Hoooooooo boy! I thought the LAST section was a lot, but here we go, even mooooooore!
